responses: Black holes have been hypothesized for about a century, but no one has ever observed one in outer space, and we have not yet been able to test the theory directly.  As far as we know, black holes are theoretical objects.

Well, you see, black holes are not really physical things in the way that, say, atoms are, because in order for something to be a black hole it must have so much gravity that it prevents light from escaping.  But there are good reasons to think black holes may exist.  
For example, it is reasonable to think that certain kinds of star are so massive that their gravity is strong enough to prevent the escape of light. responses: Post-Concussion Syndrome is a series of symptoms associated with traumatic brain injury like concussions, and includes cognitive dysfunction, emotional and behavioral symptoms, physical symptoms and sleep disorders. The syndrome is a distinct clinical diagnosis, with symptoms often persisting for months or even years after initial injury. Symptoms usually involve problems with concentration and memory, dizziness and vertigo, fatigue and irritability, emotional issues like depression and anxiety, and physical symptoms like headaches and fatigue.  While recovery is usually slow and incomplete, most patients improve over time and return to normal life, though symptoms may continue to persist for years after the injury occurs. Treatment involves supportive care for any physical or emotional symptoms, and may also include a gradual return to normal activities and cognitive rehabilitation to address persistent cognitive changes. Further treatment with psychotherapy or psychoactive medications may be needed for persistent or severe symptoms.

After any acute traumatic brain injury, such as a concussion, it is common for mild to otherwise unnoticeable symptoms to continue.  “Post-Concussion Syndrome” is the label given to these symptoms, which can include difficulty with concentration, irritability and mood changes, persistent headache, and fatigue. The severity and duration varies, and can range from mild and transient cases that go away with time, or more severe and persistent symptoms, which take weeks or months to abate.  Typical treatments include appropriate rest and restoration of normal brain metabolism, gradual return to normal activity with avoidance of stressful events, cognitive and occupational therapy, and close monitoring of clinical symptoms and changes in neurologic activity. Diagnosis and treatment can be challenging, as it is necessary to carefully differentiate Post-Concussion Syndrome from underlying pre-injury mental and cognitive health conditions, as well as complications like depressive or anxiety disorders. It is important to get proper medical attention and support throughout the recovery process, and to be honest and open with loved ones and medical professionals about any symptoms or changes you may be experiencing. Most people with Post-Concussion Syndrome make a full recovery with appropriate rest, attention and support, and children, older adults and people experiencing additional risk factors should be monitored especially closely

However, prepaid plans generally have less extensive phone coverage than other plans, so you may have more trouble making or receiving calls in certain areas.

Express empathy for the child who was hurt by your child’s behavior, and help your child understand how their behavior harmed that child.
